title: Charles Harvey (Indian Army officer)
text:
<a href="Major-general%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Major-General</a> Sir Charles Offley Harvey, <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Bath">CB</a>, <a href="Royal%20Victorian%20Order">CVO</a>, <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">CBE</a>, <a href="Military%20Cross">MC</a> (16 July 1888 – 11 October 1969) was an officer in the <a href="British%20Indian%20Army">British Indian Army</a> during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> and <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
He was appointed <a href="Royal%20Victorian%20Order">CVO</a> in 1922 for performing the duties of Assistant Military Secretary to the Prince of Wales during His
Royal Highness's Indian Tour.
In the <a href="Anglo-Soviet%20invasion%20of%20Persia">Anglo-Soviet invasion of Persia</a> he commanded <a href="8th%20Indian%20Infantry%20Division">8th Indian Infantry Division</a>, part of <a href="Paiforce">Paiforce</a>.
He was <a href="knight">knight</a>ed in 1946 for his services as Military Adviser in Chief to the <a href="Indian%20State%20Forces">Indian State Forces</a>.
He was assistant managing director of the <a href="Guinness%20Brewery">Guinness Brewery</a> with responsibility for personnel 1946-1961 and the founding chairman of the <a href="Irish%20Management%20Institute">Irish Management Institute</a> 1952-1956. He is commemorated in the IMI's Sir Charles Harvey Awards, conferred on leading MBA graduates in Irish universities.
Business career.
He was assistant managing director of the <a href="Guinness%20Brewery">Guinness Brewery</a> with responsibility for personnel from 1946-1961 and the founding chairman of the <a href="Irish%20Management%20Institute">Irish Management Institute</a> from 1952-1956. He is commemorated in the IMI's Sir Charles Harvey Awards, conferred on leading MBA graduates in Irish universities.[2]
